problems.title: Fix Real-World Audio Problems
problems.intro: Remove background noise and echo while keeping your voice natural. We fix the common issues that make speech tiring to listen to—no heavy setup needed.

items.title: Remove Background Noise
items.body: Cut constant hiss, hum, AC and traffic bed without muffling the voice. The enhancer learns the noise profile and attenuates it between words while preserving breath and presence.

items.title: Reduce Room Echo
items.body: Tame small‑room reverb and flutter echo so words start and stop crisply. Consonants remain sharp while long tails are gently reduced, improving intelligibility.

items.title: Tame Sibilance & Mouth Noises
items.body: Light de‑essing softens harsh 's' and 'sh' sounds. Clicks, lip smacks and minor crackles are smoothed so the listener focuses on the content, not artifacts.

items.title: Repair Clicks & Pops
items.body: Removes minor digital glitches and microphone pops. Subtle restoration avoids over‑processing that can smear transients or make speech sound 'underwater'.

items.title: Loudness Leveling for Podcasts
items.body: Levels uneven speakers to a comfortable, consistent perceived loudness. You get a steady listening experience across episodes and segments.

items.title: Keep It Natural
items.body: We prioritize clarity over brute force noise gating. The output remains open and natural, avoiding the 'pumping' or 'chirping' artifacts typical of aggressive cleaners.

howItWorks.title: How It Works (In Plain English)
paragraphs: We use modern speech enhancement to reduce noise and echo while keeping your voice natural and intelligible.
Workflow: upload your file → enhance → preview A/B → download the cleaned track.
Supported formats: MP3, WAV, FLAC, OGG. Recommended size: up to 50MB. No account required.
Under the hood: adaptive noise profiling + dereverberation designed for speech, followed by light de‑essing and loudness smoothing.
Why it sounds natural: the model prioritizes consonant clarity and avoids over‑aggressive gating that causes pumping or underwater tones.

steps.title: Enhance in 3 Steps
items: Upload your audio file
Click Enhance and preview the result
Download the cleaned track
steps.tip: Tip: For best results, use clips 30–120 seconds long.

details.title: Upload
details.body: Drag a file or click Select Audio. We accept MP3, WAV, FLAC and keep the original sample rate when possible. For faster preview, use 30–120s clips during editing.

details.title: Enhance & A/B
details.body: Click Enhance to start. When finished, use the player to compare and focus on the noise floor, reverb tail, and consonant clarity. If artifacts appear, try a shorter segment or a cleaner source.

details.title: Download & Publish
details.body: Export the cleaned track. Stereo is preserved; import into your editor or DAW. For podcasts, normalize the final mix around −16 LUFS (mono around −19).

bestPractices.title: Best Practices for Clearer Recordings
items: Keep a steady mic distance and angle; use a pop filter or windscreen.
Reduce room reflections with soft furnishings.
Avoid clipping; set a healthy input level.
For podcasts, aim around −16 LUFS to keep loudness consistent.
For extreme noise or echo, consider re‑recording or advanced DAW tools.
Record in a quiet room; turn off AC or fans and close windows.
Place the mic 10–20 cm from the mouth, slightly off‑axis to reduce plosives.
Record 5–10 seconds of room tone at the start to help any cleaner learn the noise floor.

compatibility.title: Compatibility & Limits
items: Formats: MP3, WAV, FLAC, OGG; file size up to 50MB.

Language: optimized for speech in any language; best with clear articulation.

items: Temporary processing for enhancement only.
Your audio isn’t used to train models.
No login required.

items.q: Will denoising make my voice sound metallic?
items.a: We balance noise reduction with intelligibility to keep your voice natural. Extreme noise may still cause artifacts—lighter cleanup or re‑recording can help.
Yes, typical hum and low‑frequency rumble can be reduced effectively.

items.q: How much echo can it reduce?
items.a: Moderate room echo can be improved; very strong reverb may require re‑recording or advanced tools.

items.q: Will it improve very noisy recordings?
items.a: It helps, but extremely low signal‑to‑noise sources are challenging. Capture the best possible audio at the source when you can.

items.q: Is the output podcast‑ready for loudness?
items.a: Results are leveled for comfortable listening. For strict platform specs, double‑check LUFS before publishing.

items.q: What file formats and sizes are supported?
items.a: MP3, WAV, FLAC, OGG; up to 50MB per file.
Processing is temporary and purpose‑only; audio is not used to train models.
Most files enhance in seconds to a couple of minutes, depending on length and network conditions.
The default setting avoids over‑processing. For advanced control, consider a DAW workflow.

items.q: Can I use it for music?
items.a: It’s optimized for speech; light cleanup on music may work, but detailed music restoration is better done in a DAW.

items.q: What if the result breathes or pumps?
items.a: This can happen when background noise is very dynamic. Try trimming to the spoken sections, or record more consistent room tone.
Severe clipping cannot be fully repaired. Reduce input gain during recording and keep peaks below 0 dBFS.
